ensures that only optimized kernels are called when using the GPU. Additionally, the
function is shown as a way to translate models and data over to the GPU. Note that this function is CPU-safe, so if the GPU is disabled or unavailable, this code will fallback to the CPU.
where the raw MNIST data is split into features
will then transform the current labels (

meaning that every minibatch will contain 128 images with a single color channel of 28x28 pixels. The entire dataset of 60,000 images is split into the train and test dataset, ensuring a balanced ratio of labels. These splits are then passed to Flux's DataLoader. This automatically minibatches both the images and labels. Additionally, it allows us to shuffle the train dataset in each epoch while keeping the order of the test data the same.
# Use MLDataUtils LabelEnc for natural onehot conversion
# Use Flux's DataLoader to automatically minibatch and shuffle the data

# Main
const bs = 128
const train_split = 0.9
train_dataloader, test_dataloader = loadmnist(bs, train_split)
The Neural Network requires passing inputs sequentially through multiple layers. We use
which allows inputs to functions to come from previous layer and sends the outputs to the next. Four different sets of layers are used here:
: This layer downsamples our images into a 20 dimensional feature vector. It takes a 28 x 28 image, flattens it, and then passes it through a fully connected layer with
: A 3 layers Deep Neural Network Chain with
activation which is used to model our differential equation
: The final fully connected layer which maps our learned feature vector to the probability of the feature vector of belonging to a particular class
: An utility function which transfers our model to GPU, if it is available
to a Matrix (CuArray), and reduces the matrix from 3 to 2 dimensions for use in the next layer.
For CPU: If this function does not automatically fallback to CPU when no GPU is present, we can change
Next we connect all layers together in a single chain:
